You said:
I've got a supabase postgresql database created and have found its connection string. I want to use the string in my django/flutter app in dev. I need to set up an env or .env file so that the string is not exposed when and if I deploy. Can you walk me through how to do that?
ChatGPT said:

Got it 👍 — you’ve got a Supabase PostgreSQL connection string and want to keep it safe (not hardcoded in your Django or Flutter apps). Let’s walk through the setup step by step for both Django (backend) and Flutter (frontend).

🔹 Step 1: Copy your Supabase connection string

It’ll look something like this:

bash
postgresql://postgres:YOUR_PASSWORD@db.xxxxx.supabase.co:5432/postgres

🔹 Step 2: Create a .env file

At the root of your Django project (where manage.py lives), create a file named .env:

ini
# .env
DATABASE_URL=postgresql://postgres:YOUR_PASSWORD@db.xxxxx.supabase.co:5432/postgres

⚠️ Never commit .env to GitHub. Add it to your .gitignore file:

bash
# .gitignore
.env

🔹 Step 3: Install python-dotenv (for Django)

bash
pip install python-dotenv

Then, in your settings.py, load the environment variables:

python
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
import dj_database_url

# Load variables from .env
load_dotenv()

DATABASES = {
    "default": dj_database_url.config(default=os.getenv("DATABASE_URL"))
}

✅ Now Django will connect to Supabase without hardcoding the string.

🔹 Step 4: Flutter side

Flutter should not directly connect to your Postgres database — that’s insecure.
Instead, Flutter should only talk to your Django backend (via API), and Django talks to Supabase.

But if you want Flutter to hold API keys or base URLs in dev, you can still use a .env-like setup.

  1. Add the package:

bash
flutter pub add flutter_dotenv

  1. Create a .env file in your Flutter project:

ini
# .env
API_URL=http://10.0.2.2:8000   # Django dev server (Android emulator)

  1. Load it in main.dart:

dart
import 'package:flutter_dotenv/flutter_dotenv.dart';

Future<void> main() async {
  await dotenv.load(fileName: ".env");
  runApp(MyApp());
}

// Example usage
final apiUrl = dotenv.env['API_URL'];

🔹 Step 5: Deployment

  • On Heroku, Railway, or Supabase Functions, you don’t use .env files directly — you set env vars in the platform’s dashboard.

  • Locally: .env file.

  • In production: configure through host provider (Django reads them the same way).

✅ Summary:

  • Put your Supabase DATABASE_URL in .env.

  • Load it with python-dotenv + dj-database-url in Django.

  • Never expose that connection string to Flutter.

  • Flutter should only store safe values like API_URL in its .env.

Do you want me to also show you how to switch automatically between dev and prod configs (so that locally you use .env, but in production Django just uses the host’s env vars)?

You said:
I need to find my db password!
ChatGPT said:

Cool — let’s get that password located (or replaced) quickly and safely. Below are several ways to find or reset the DB password for a Supabase Postgres instance plus the follow-up steps you must take after changing anything.

1) Quickest — extract it from the connection string you already found

Your connection string looks like:

bash
postgresql://postgres:YOUR_PASSWORD@db.xxxxx.supabase.co:5432/postgres

The password is the part between the first : after the username and the @.
Example extraction (shell):

bash
# replace the example with your full connection string
CONN="postgresql://postgres:Abc%40123@db.xxxxx.supabase.co:5432/postgres"
echo "$CONN" | sed -E 's#.*postgres:([^@]+)@.*#\1#'
# prints: Abc%40123

Note: the password in the URL may be URL-encoded (e.g. @ → %40). If you need the decoded version:

bash
# decode percent-encoding (uses python)
python -c "import urllib.parse as u; print(u.unquote('Abc%40123'))"
# prints: Abc@123

Or use Python to parse the full URL and show the password:

python
from urllib.parse import urlparse, unquote
u = urlparse("postgresql://postgres:Abc%40123@db.xxxxx.supabase.co:5432/postgres")
print(unquote(u.password))

2) Reveal or reset via the Supabase dashboard

  • Open your Supabase project dashboard.

  • Go to Project Settings → Database (sometimes shown as just Database in the left menu).

  • Look for Connection string or Connection info. There may be a “Reveal” / “Show” button for the password.

  • If it is not shown or you don’t want to reveal the existing password, use the Reset database password (or similar) button in the same section.

Important: resetting the DB password will immediately break any services using the old password — you must update all DATABASE_URL env vars and restart/deploy those services.

3) Change the password with SQL (if you prefer)

If you can run SQL (e.g. via Supabase SQL editor or psql), you can change the password for a role:

sql
ALTER USER postgres WITH PASSWORD 'NewS3cretP@ssw0rd';

If Supabase prevents altering the default postgres user, use the dashboard reset option instead.

4) After you find or reset the password — what to do next

  1. Update your .env (development) and any platform environment variables (production). Example .env:

    ini
    DATABASE_URL=postgresql://postgres:NewS3cretP%40ssw0rd@db.xxxxx.supabase.co:5432/postgres

    If the password has special characters, URL-encode them (or use libraries that accept separate user/password fields).

  2. Restart your services (Django dev server, any workers, CI, deploy pipeline) so they pick up the new env var.

  3. Don’t commit .env to git — ensure .gitignore contains .env.

  4. Rotate any leaked credentials — if the password was ever exposed (public repo, screenshot, etc.), rotate it immediately and revoke any access keys that may have been combined with it.

5) Troubleshooting tips

  • If Django keeps failing to connect after updating DATABASE_URL, ensure the password is correctly URL-encoded. Example: @ → %40, : → %3A.

  • If you changed the password and still can’t connect, check firewall/allowed IPs in Supabase (Project → Network) and confirm the DB host and port are correct.

  • If you have connection pooling (PgBouncer) enabled, you may need to restart the pool or wait a short moment for caches to clear.

If you want, tell me (don’t need to paste the real string — you can paste an anonymized example) which method you prefer and I’ll give the exact commands/snippets for your environment (Django .env line, how to update it on your host, and a safe way to URL-encode a password).

You said:
I can't see my .env file on the project explorer. Should I change the view settings for the explorer?
ChatGPT said:

Exactly 🙂 — by default, most editors (VS Code, Android Studio, PyCharm, etc.) hide dotfiles (files that start with a .). That includes .env.

Here’s what you can do depending on your editor:

🔹 VS Code

  • In the Explorer pane, click the … menu (top right).

  • Check “Show Hidden Files”.

  • Alternatively, press Ctrl+Shift+P → search for files.exclude → make sure .env isn’t excluded.

🔹 PyCharm / IntelliJ

  • In the Project tool window, click the gear icon ⚙️.

  • Uncheck “Hide dotfiles”.

🔹 Android Studio

  • Same as IntelliJ: go to the Project window → gear icon ⚙️ → uncheck “Hide dotfiles”.

🔹 Terminal check

Regardless of the editor, you can always confirm the file exists by listing hidden files in your project root:

bash
ls -a

If .env shows up in that list, you’re good. If not, you may not have created it yet — in that case:

bash
touch .env

✅ Once it’s visible, you’ll be able to open and edit it normally.

You said:
Where's the project tool window in android studio?
ChatGPT said:

In Android Studio, the Project tool window is basically the file explorer for your project.

You’ll usually find it:

  • Docked on the left side of the IDE (a vertical panel).

  • If it’s hidden, look for a tab labeled “Project” along the left edge of the window — click it to open.

  • Or, press the shortcut:

    • Windows/Linux: Alt+1

    • Mac: Cmd+1

Once it’s open, you’ll see the tree of all your project files (like lib/, android/, etc. in Flutter).

➡️ At the top of that panel, there’s a dropdown menu where you can change the view (Android, Project, Packages, etc.). To see all files, switch it to Project view.

Then, to show hidden files (like .env):

  1. Click the little gear ⚙️ icon in the Project tool window.

  2. Uncheck “Hide dotfiles”.

Now .env should show up in the file tree.

You said:
I need to use the dj-database-url
ChatGPT said:

Perfect — dj-database-url is exactly what you want. It lets you use a single DATABASE_URL string in your .env and parses it into Django’s DATABASES dict automatically. Here’s how to set it up step by step:

1️⃣ Install the package

In your Django virtual environment:

bash
pip install dj-database-url

2️⃣ Add your .env variable

In the project root (next to manage.py), your .env should have:

ini
# .env
DATABASE_URL=postgresql://postgres:YOUR_PASSWORD@db.xxxxx.supabase.co:5432/postgres

3️⃣ Update settings.py

Open backend/backend/settings.py (the inner folder), and add:

python
import os
import dj_database_url
from dotenv import load_dotenv

# Load .env variables from project root
load_dotenv()

DATABASES = {
    "default": dj_database_url.config(
        default=os.getenv("DATABASE_URL"),  # reads your .env
        conn_max_age=600,                   # optional: persistent connections
        ssl_require=True                    # optional: Supabase requires SSL
    )
}

  • conn_max_age keeps database connections alive (good for performance).

  • ssl_require=True ensures Django connects securely (Supabase requires SSL).

4️⃣ Optional: Debug

To make sure Django picked up the URL:

python
print(DATABASES["default"])

Run:

bash
python manage.py shell

You should see a dict with ENGINE, NAME, USER, PASSWORD, HOST, PORT.

✅ That’s it! Now Django will automatically parse your Supabase connection string and connect securely.

I have to define my models before running migrations. Where do I write my models in this case?
ChatGPT said:

Exactly — before running migrations, Django needs your models defined. Here’s how it works step by step:

1️⃣ Where models go

In Django, models are defined per app, not in the project-level settings.py.

Typical structure:

java
backend/             ← project root (manage.py here)
├─ backend/          ← project folder (settings.py, urls.py)
│  ├─ __init__.py
│  ├─ settings.py
│  ├─ urls.py
│  └─ wsgi.py
└─ lessons/          ← this is your Django app
   ├─ __init__.py
   ├─ admin.py
   ├─ apps.py
   ├─ models.py     ← define your models here
   ├─ views.py
   └─ migrations/

So each app has a models.py. That’s where you write your model classes.

2️⃣ Example: a simple model

In lessons/models.py:

python
from django.db import models

class Language(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    level = models.CharField(max_length=50)
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.name} ({self.level})"

3️⃣ Tell Django about your app

Make sure your app is listed in INSTALLED_APPS in backend/settings.py:

python
INSTALLED_APPS = [
    'django.contrib.admin',
    'django.contrib.auth',
    'django.contrib.contenttypes',
    'django.contrib.sessions',
    'django.contrib.messages',
    'django.contrib.staticfiles',

    'lessons',  # ← add your app here
]

4️⃣ Create migrations

Once your models are defined:

bash
python manage.py makemigrations lessons

  • This creates migration files in lessons/migrations/.

Then apply them to the database:

bash
python manage.py migrate

✅ Summary

  1. Models go in the models.py of each app.

  2. Register your app in INSTALLED_APPS.

  3. Run makemigrations → migrate.

ChatGPT said:

Perfect — you’re thinking about this the right way. Let’s break it down carefully.

1️⃣ App structure

You’ll need at least two apps to separate the “metadata” about languages/levels/topics” from the actual exercises. For example:

java
backend/             ← Django project root (manage.py)
├─ backend/          ← project folder (settings.py, urls.py)
└─ exercises/        ← app for exercises
└─ metadata/         ← app for languages, levels, topics

  • metadata → Languages, Fluency Levels, Topics

  • exercises → Exercises, each pointing to a Topic and Level

This keeps a healthy separation of concerns.

2️⃣ Locale codes: underscore vs hyphen

  • Python / Django convention: underscore (_).

  • Examples:

nginx
de_DE
en_GB
es_ES
ga_IE

  • This matches ISO 639 language codes + ISO 3166 country codes, and Django’s internal locale system expects underscores.

  • Hyphen (-) is often used in URLs, front-end JS, or Accept-Language headers. But in your DB and Python models, use _.

3️⃣ Define the fluency levels

Since these are fixed, you can use a model or choices tuple:

python
# metadata/models.py
from django.db import models

class FluencyLevel(models.TextChoices):
    A1 = "A1", "A1 (Beginner)"
    A2 = "A2", "A2"
    B1 = "B1", "B1"
    B2 = "B2", "B2"
    C1 = "C1", "C1"
    C2 = "C2", "C2"

  • This makes it easy to reference in other models.

  • You could also store levels in a DB table if you want them editable later, but for now TextChoices is cleaner.

4️⃣ Languages

python
# metadata/models.py
class Language(models.Model):
    code = models.CharField(max_length=5, unique=True)  # de_DE, en_GB, etc.
    name = models.CharField(max_length=50)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.name} ({self.code})"

  • Seed your DB with the four languages.

5️⃣ Topics

python
class Topic(models.Model):
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    language = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    level = models.CharField(max_length=2, choices=FluencyLevel.choices, default=FluencyLevel.A1)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.name} ({self.language.code}, {self.level})"

6️⃣ Exercises

python
# exercises/models.py
from django.db import models
from metadata.models import Topic, FluencyLevel

class Exercise(models.Model):
    title = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    topic = models.ForeignKey(Topic, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    level = models.CharField(max_length=2, choices=FluencyLevel.choices)
    question_text = models.TextField()
    answer_text = models.TextField()

    def __str__(self):
        return self.title

  • Each exercise is linked to a topic and a level, but doesn’t need to store the language separately (it’s in topic.language).

✅ Summary

  • Use underscore (_) in locale codes for Python/Django.

  • Keep metadata and exercises separate.

  • Fluency levels: use TextChoices for simplicity.

  • Topics belong to a language and a level.

  • Exercises point to a topic and a level.

ChatGPT said:

Got it — you want to rename the “metadata” app to langleveltopic. Let’s go over Django naming conventions so it’s clean and maintainable.

1️⃣ App folder / Python module name

  • All lowercase, no spaces.

  • Underscores are allowed and often recommended for readability.

  • Hyphens (-) are not allowed in Python module names.

So valid names for your app:

text
langleveltopic       # simple, fine
lang_level_topic     # more readable

Avoid LangLevelTopic (capital letters) or lang-level-topic (hyphens) because Python module names must be valid identifiers.

2️⃣ Django conventions

  • App names are usually lowercase, single word or underscores.

  • Folder name = module name = app name in INSTALLED_APPS.

Examples from Django docs:

nginx
polls
admin
auth
contenttypes
sessions

  • Multi-word apps usually use underscores: user_profile, blog_posts.

3️⃣ Recommendations for your case

You have two options:

OptionProsCons
langleveltopicMatches what you typed, simpleSlightly hard to read
lang_level_topicMore readable, clearly separates wordsSlightly longer

Either works; just stay lowercase and use underscores if you want readability.

You said:
So ... what do you recommend adding to my language table in the langleveltopics app
ChatGPT said:

Great — let’s design the Language table carefully so it’s flexible, clear, and aligned with Django conventions. Since this is the foundation for your exercises, it should include enough info to identify languages, but not overcomplicate things.

Recommended fields for Language model

FieldTypeNotes
codeCharField(max_length=5, unique=True)ISO locale code (de_DE, en_GB, es_ES, ga_IE). Use underscores.
nameCharField(max_length=50)Human-readable language name (Deutsch, English, Spanish, Irish).
native_nameCharField(max_length=50, blank=True, null=True)Optional: native version of the language name. Useful for multilingual displays.
directionCharField(max_length=3, choices=[('ltr','Left-to-Right'),('rtl','Right-to-Left')], default='ltr')Optional: text direction. Defaults to ltr. Only necessary if you anticipate RTL languages later.
activeBooleanField(default=True)Optional: if you want to easily enable/disable languages without deleting records.
created_atDateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)Record creation timestamp.
updated_atDateTimeField(auto_now=True)Record last update timestamp.

Example Django model

python
# langleveltopics/models.py
from django.db import models

class Language(models.Model):
    code = models.CharField(max_length=5, unique=True)  # de_DE, en_GB, etc.
    name = models.CharField(max_length=50)
    native_name = models.CharField(max_length=50, blank=True, null=True)
    direction = models.CharField(
        max_length=3,
        choices=[('ltr', 'Left-to-Right'), ('rtl', 'Right-to-Left')],
        default='ltr'
    )
    active = models.BooleanField(default=True)
    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)
    updated_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.name} ({self.code})"

Notes / rationale

  1. code is essential — it will link to topics, exercises, and potentially frontend locale switching.

  2. native_name is optional, but useful if you want a multilingual interface.

  3. direction future-proofs the table for RTL languages (Hebrew, Arabic, etc.) without changing the schema later.

  4. active is optional but makes maintenance easier.

  5. Timestamps are always helpful for auditing or sorting.

You have two main paths:

🔹 Option 1. Rename the project in place

  2. Copy over your existing .env, requirements.txt, and any configs you’ve set up (database URL, dj-database-url, etc.).

  3. Delete the old language_lessons_app.

This is usually safer and avoids missing references when renaming.

Go with Option 2 (fresh project) — it will take 5 minutes, and you’ll have a clean base you can reuse and clone.

bash

Step 1: Models for langleveltopics

Here’s a clean starting point:

python
# langleveltopics/models.py

from django.db import models


class Language(models.Model):
    """
    Represents a natural language that exercises can be tied to.
    Example: English (en_GB), Deutsch (de_DE), etc.
    """
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100, unique=True)  # Human-readable
    code = models.CharField(max_length=10, unique=True)   # Locale-style code (en_GB, de_DE, etc.)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.name} ({self.code})"


class Level(models.Model):
    """
    CEFR levels of fluency (A1, A2, B1, B2, C1, C2).
    """
    name = models.CharField(max_length=20, unique=True)   # e.g. "A1"
    description = models.CharField(max_length=200, blank=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return self.name


class Topic(models.Model):
    """
    A thematic unit for exercises, tied to a language.
    Example: Food, Travel, Grammar, Conversation.
    """
    language = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="topics")
    name = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    description = models.TextField(blank=True)

    class Meta:
        unique_together = ("language", "name")  # avoid duplicate "Food" topics in the same language

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.name} ({self.language.code})"

Step 2: Models for exercises

These will connect back to the above:

python
# exercises/models.py

from django.db import models
from langleveltopics.models import Language, Level, Topic


class Exercise(models.Model):
    """
    Represents a single exercise tied to a topic and a fluency level.
    """
    language = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="exercises")
    level = models.ForeignKey(Level, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="exercises")
    topic = models.ForeignKey(Topic, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="exercises")

    title = models.CharField(max_length=200)
    content = models.TextField()  # could be question text, JSON, etc.

    created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.title} [{self.language.code}, {self.level.name}]"

I want to make a Language model with two fields: ISO_code and ID (provided by Django) I also want a LangName model with four fields: ID (provided by Django) NameText (a text giving a written name) Lang_ISO (the ISO code for the language being referred to) Text_ISO (the ISO code of the language in which the NameText is written) Am I overcomplicating it?
ChatGPT said:

That’s a really good design question — and you’re not overcomplicating, you’re just thinking carefully about internationalisation of names 👍. Let’s break it down.

What you’re proposing

  • Language

    • id (Django default PK)

    • ISO_code (unique identifier like en_GB, de_DE, etc.)

  • LangName

    • id (Django default PK)

    • NameText (e.g. "German", "Deutsch", "alemán")

    • Lang_ISO → which language the name refers to (de_DE)

    • Text_ISO → which language the name is written in (en_GB, de_DE, es_ES)

Why this is interesting

  • It gives you true multilingual metadata.

  • You can display "Deutsch" to a German user, "German" to an English user, "alemán" to a Spanish user, all referring to the same Language record.

  • This is how big localisation systems (CLDR, Unicode) often work.

Is it overcomplicated?

It depends on your goals:

  • If you just need a quick project:
    You can keep Language with only id + ISO_code, and hardcode a small mapping in code (like a dict of ISO → names).

  • If you want scalability and proper i18n from the start:
    Your LangName model is a great idea. It avoids hardcoding, and lets you add new display names later without touching code.

Implementation sketch

python
# langleveltopics/models.py

from django.db import models


class Language(models.Model):
    ISO_code = models.CharField(max_length=10, unique=True)

    def __str__(self):
        return self.ISO_code


class LangName(models.Model):
    NameText = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    Lang_ISO = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="names")
    Text_ISO = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="translations")

    class Meta:
        unique_together = ("Lang_ISO", "Text_ISO")  # prevent duplicates

    def __str__(self):
        return f"{self.NameText} ({self.Text_ISO.ISO_code}) → {self.Lang_ISO.ISO_code}"

✅ This way:

  • You can have Lang_ISO = de_DE, Text_ISO = en_GB, NameText = "German".

  • Or Lang_ISO = de_DE, Text_ISO = es_ES, NameText = "alemán".

  • Or Lang_ISO = de_DE, Text_ISO = de_DE, NameText = "Deutsch".

ChatGPT said:

Crystal clear 👌 — you’ve laid out a serious and scalable architecture. Let’s untangle the design, check for pitfalls, and then talk relational (Postgres) vs document (MongoDB).

🧩 What you have so far

  • Languages → multilingual names via LangName. ✅

  • Levels → fixed set (A1–C2), shared across all languages. ✅

  • Topics → belong to a single language, conditioned by levels. ✅

  • Lessons →

    • bound to one topic, one language, one level

    • have intro (title + paragraph, rich text)

    • full body = intro + ordered rich-text segments (JSON-based, potentially reused)

  • Exercises →

    • pool linked to a lesson

    • each exercise = prompt + candidate solutions (at least one correct)

    • associated with multiple topics and levels (many-to-many)

    • complexity derived from linguistic features (grammar, vocab)

✅ The logic makes sense

This is exactly how you’d model a language-learning app backend:

  • Keep metadata normalized (languages, levels, topics).

  • Keep actual content flexible (rich text, lessons, exercises).

  • Allow reuse of texts and exercises across contexts.
    You’re building the same patterns Duolingo or LingQ rely on.

🔄 SQL (Postgres) vs NoSQL (MongoDB)

PostgreSQL (with JSONB fields)

  • Pros:

    • Strong relational structure (good for languages/levels/topics/exercises).

    • JSONB fields let you embed arbitrary JSON for lesson content.

    • Easy to query both structured (relations) and unstructured (JSON) data.

    • Works seamlessly with Django ORM.

    • Avoids splitting your stack across two DB systems.

  • Cons:

    • If your JSON lesson structures get wildly complex, queries may get clumsy.

    • Requires some thought about indexing JSONB fields for performance.

MongoDB

  • Pros:

    • Native fit for hierarchical JSON-like lesson structures.

    • Flexible schema evolution — no migrations required.

    • Very fast for document retrieval if lessons/exercises are deeply nested.

  • Cons:

    • You’ll lose relational integrity (no real FKs, JOINs, constraints).

    • Exercises/topics/levels cross-linking becomes awkward.

    • Django support is weaker (there’s Djongo and MongoEngine, but they’re not first-class citizens like Postgres).

    • You’d need to manage two databases (Postgres for metadata, Mongo for lessons), which adds devops overhead.

🚦 Recommendation

Since you’re aiming for iOS + Android production release and already using Supabase (Postgres):

  • Stick with Postgres + JSONB.

  • Model lessons + exercises relationally where needed, and push variable-length structured content into JSONField.

This gives you the best of both worlds:

  • Clean, enforceable schema for languages, levels, topics, relationships.

  • Flexible, evolvable storage for lesson text and exercise pools.

🛠️ Practical model idea (simplified sketch)

python
from django.db import models


class Language(models.Model):
    ISO_code = models.CharField(max_length=10, unique=True)


class LangName(models.Model):
    NameText = models.CharField(max_length=100)
    Lang_ISO = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="names")
    Text_ISO = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="translations")

    class Meta:
        unique_together = ("Lang_ISO", "Text_ISO")


class Level(models.Model):
    code = models.CharField(max_length=2, unique=True)  # A1, A2, B1…
    order = models.PositiveSmallIntegerField()  # 1–6


class Topic(models.Model):
    language = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    level = models.ForeignKey(Level, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    key = models.CharField(max_length=100)  # stable reference
    names = models.JSONField(default=dict)  # {"en_GB": "Travel", "de_DE": "Reisen"}


class Lesson(models.Model):
    language = models.ForeignKey(Language, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    topic = models.ForeignKey(Topic, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    level = models.ForeignKey(Level, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
    intro = models.JSONField(default=dict)  # {"title": "...", "paragraph": "..."}
    body = models.JSONField(default=list)   # [{"title": "X", "text": "Y"}, ...]


class Exercise(models.Model):
    lesson = models.ForeignKey(Lesson, on_delete=models.CASCADE, related_name="exercises")
    topics = models.ManyToManyField(Topic)
    levels = models.ManyToManyField(Level)
    prompt = models.TextField()
    solutions = models.JSONField(default=list)  # [{"answer": "cat", "correct": True}, ...]

🔑 Key benefits of this structure

  • Relational core for linking things together (lessons → topics → languages → levels).

  • JSON fields for rich text and flexible exercises.

  • Clean expansion path if you later add speech, audio, or AI-generated hints.
